channel.title: NYT > Top Stories

item.title: Markets Fall After Higher-Than-Expected Inflation Data
item.description: Stocks plunged, government bond yields soared and the dollar bounced after investors were wrong-footed by data showing stubbornly high price increases last month.
item.dc:creator: Joe Rennison

item.title: The Critical Moment Behind Ukraine’s Rapid Advance
item.description: President Volodymyr Zelensky wanted to make a dramatic move in the war against Russia. U.S. and Ukrainian officials came up with a plan.
item.dc:creator: Julian E. Barnes, Eric Schmitt and Helene Cooper
item.media:credit: Jim Huylebroek for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ukrainian soldiers near the Kherson front this month.

item.title: Clashes Erupt Between Armenia and Azerbaijan in Nagorno-Karabakh
item.description: The simmering conflict over the disputed Nagorno-Karabakh region last flared in 2020, when Russia brokered a cease-fire.
item.dc:creator: Ivan Nechepurenko and Cora Engelbrecht
item.media:credit: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times
item.media:description: Armenian soldiers and a Russian peacekeeping soldier, on the vehicle, at a checkpoint in Nagorno-Karabakh in 2020.

item.title: Challenges for Russia and China Test a ‘No-Limits’ Friendship
item.description: Vladimir Putin and Xi Jinping are set to meet later this week. Russia’s battlefield losses and China’s slowdown could complicate their relationship.
item.dc:creator: Keith Bradsher, Anton Troianovski and Jane Perlez
item.media:credit: Alexei Druzhinin/Sputnik, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia, left, and China’s top leader, Xi Jinping, in Beijing in February. The two are expected to meet again this week in Uzbekistan.

item.title: Xi’s China and Biden’s U.S.: It Feels Like a Cold War
item.description: Even at their worst moments, the Americans and the Soviets kept talking. Today, U.S.-China contacts are scarce, while Beijing and Moscow move closer together.
item.dc:creator: Jane Perlez
item.media:description: President Biden during a virtual meeting in November with Xi Jinping, China’s leader. They have spoken only five times since early 2021.

item.title: How King Charles Turned His Royal Estate Into a Lucrative Portfolio
item.description: As prince, Charles used tax breaks, offshore accounts and canny real estate investments to turn a sleepy estate into a billion-dollar business.
item.dc:creator: Jane Bradley and Euan Ward
item.category: Charles III, King of the United Kingdom
Elizabeth II, Queen of Great Britain
item.media:credit: James Hill for The New York Times
item.media:description: King Charles III spent years turning his royal estate into a billion-dollar portfolio.

item.title: How Time Softened Judgment of Camilla and Fury Over Diana’s Death
item.description: A quarter-century ago Princess Diana’s shocking death provoked outrage at the royal family. Queen Elizabeth’s passing, in contrast, has been draped in civility and respect.
item.dc:creator: Sarah Lyall
item.category: Elizabeth II, Queen of Great Britain
item.media:credit: Dan Kitwood/Agence France-Presse, via Pool/Afp Via Getty Images
item.media:description: King Charles III and Camilla, the queen consort, made an appearance on Monday before British lawmakers.

item.title: When the Queen Died, Someone Had to Tell the Bees
item.description: A report that the royal beekeeper had informed Queen Elizabeth II’s bees of her death received some mockery, but it has been a tradition for centuries.
item.dc:creator: Daniel Victor
item.category: Elizabeth II, Queen of Great Britain

item.title: Andrew Sean Greer on His New Novel, ‘Less Is Lost’
item.description: Andrew Sean Greer was elated, if a little confounded, when his 2017 novel “Less” received the award. Now he’s following it with a sequel, which he knows might raise some eyebrows. So what if it’s unseemly?
item.dc:creator: Alexandra Alter
item.media:credit: Sara Naomi Lewkowicz for The New York Times
item.media:description: Greer wrote things in “Less” that he thought “no one would ever read.” Then the book won the Pulitzer. “It’s a little shocking now.”

item.title: Graham Proposes 15-Week Abortion Ban, Seeking to Unite Republicans
item.description: The South Carolina senator’s bill was an effort to unite his party behind a position before the midterm elections, in which abortion rights are expected to be a potent issue.
item.dc:creator: Annie Karni
item.media:description: Senator Lindsey Graham’s proposal was an effort to politically insulate Republicans from voter backlash after a Supreme Court ruling in June ended the constitutional right to abortion.

item.title: Why Things May Really Be Different for This Midterm Election
item.description: This cycle, the arguments for Democratic strength cut against the conventional wisdom that the party in power struggles in midterms.
item.dc:creator: Nate Cohn

item.title: New NY Rules Offer Road Map for Regulating Private Hasidic Schools
item.description: The State Board of Regents on Tuesday enacted regulations aimed at holding New York private schools to minimum academic standards.
item.dc:creator: Brian M. Rosenthal and Eliza Shapiro
item.media:credit: Jonah Markowitz for The New York Times
item.media:description: New York’s private Hasidic schools could face more oversight under new rules enacted by a state education panel.

item.title: In Hasidic Enclaves, Failing Yeshivas Flush With Public Money
item.description: New York’s Hasidic Jewish religious schools have benefited from $1 billion in government funding in the last four years but are unaccountable to outside oversight.
item.dc:creator: Eliza Shapiro, Brian M. Rosenthal and Jonah Markowitz
item.media:credit: Jonah Markowitz for The New York Times

item.title: Godard Taught Me How to Watch Cinema, Even as He Kept Reinventing It
item.description: Jean-Luc Godard was a prophet of film’s future as an art form, layering images and sound that the body could sink into and the mind could puzzle through.
item.dc:creator: Manohla Dargis

item.title: 9 Great Godard Films to Stream Now
item.description: From the youthful New Wave excitement of “Breathless” to the experimental works of his old age, Godard changed cinema.
item.dc:creator: Noel Murray

item.title: The Best and Worst Moments of the 2022 Emmys
item.description: The show returned to a pre-Covid format, with the usual array of leaden gags, shameless commercialism and genuinely poignant moments.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:credit: Patrick T. Fallon/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: The Emmy host, Kenan Thompson, bottom center, opened the show with a number based on TV theme songs.

item.title: The Endless Torment of the ‘Recipe?’ Guy
item.description: A rampant internet comment that just won’t die shows how recipes, and the people who develop them, are undervalued.
item.dc:creator: Tejal Rao

item.title: Sally Schmitt’s French Laundry
item.description: Sally Schmitt sold the French Laundry. Then it became “the best restaurant in the world.”
item.dc:creator: Ben Proudfoot

item.title: It Is a Well-Known Truth That Opponents of Democracy Don’t Want You to Have Nice Things
item.description: What makes a democracy robust?
item.dc:creator: Jamelle Bouie
item.media:description: Striking bus drivers in Boston in 1987.

item.title: The Greatest Threat to Democracy Is a Feature of Democracy
item.description: Democratic society is uniquely vulnerable to the consequences of communication.
item.dc:creator: Sean Illing and Zac Gershberg

item.title: A Look at the Misery Index and Inflation
item.description: Surprise! Good news on inflation.
item.dc:creator: Paul Krugman
item.media:credit: Sarah Silbiger for The New York Times

item.title: ‘Quiet Quitting’ Is Not the Solution to Burnout
item.description: As counterintuitive as it seems, adding energizing activities to your schedule just might make life feel more doable.
item.dc:creator: Laura Vanderkam

item.title: Friedrich Schelling’s Philosophy Can Help Us Through the Climate Crisis
item.description: Friedrich Schelling’s ideas might provide a foundation on which to anchor the fight for our climate and our survival.
item.dc:creator: Andrea Wulf

item.title: We Build Civilizations on Status. But We Barely Understand It.
item.description: The sociologist Cecilia Ridgeway explains how status shapes our world — and our lives.
item.dc:creator: ‘The Ezra Klein Show’
item.category: Status: Why Is It Everywhere? Why Does It Matter? (Book)

item.title: Ukraine on the March
item.description: It’s not just one region. Ukraine is making progress in multiple places.
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt
item.media:description: A Ukrainian tank in the Kharkiv region yesterday.

item.title: Is Ukraine Turning the Tide in the War?
item.description: What the country’s biggest victory since the beginning of the war means for the future of the conflict.
item.dc:creator: Sabrina Tavernise, Rob Szypko, Sydney Harper, Mooj Zadie, M.J. Davis Lin, Lisa Chow, Dan Powell, Rowan Niemisto, Marion Lozano and Chris Wood
item.media:description: A Ukrainian soldier on an abandoned Russian tank last week. The Ukrainians have launched a stunning counteroffensive against Russia.

item.title: Jennifer Egan and the Goon Squad
item.description: The novelist talks about her Pulitzer-winning book, which includes one chapter written as a PowerPoint presentation, and Stephen Fry discusses Greek mythology.

item.title: Breakfast With Grandma
item.description: A new New Yorker tucks into the West Village’s offerings with her Abueti, a longtime Manhattanite.
item.dc:creator: Tanya Sichynsky
item.media:description: If you need a more portable breakfast, St. Jardim’s egg sandwich with smoked bacon, tomato jam and greens always satisfies.

item.title: NBA Fines and Suspends Phoenix Suns Owner Robert Sarver
item.description: An investigation found that the owner, Robert Sarver, had used racial slurs and treated female employees inequitably. The N.B.A. fined Sarver $10 million.
item.dc:creator: Scott Cacciola and Tania Ganguli
item.media:description: Robert Sarver, the owner of the Phoenix Suns and the Phoenix Mercury, has been suspended for one year after an investigation found that he had mistreated employees.

item.title: To Save Whales, Don’t Eat Lobster, Watchdog Group Says
item.description: The group says that the shellfish, long considered a more responsible choice, cannot be considered a guilt-free meal anymore.
item.dc:creator: Annie Roth
item.media:description: Seafood Watch red-listed American lobsters, which are fished off Maine, Canada’s maritime provinces and other parts of the Northwest Atlantic.

item.title: ‘The Future of Hospitals’: Flexible Space for the Next Pandemic
item.description: After struggling to respond to a crushing Covid caseload, many hospitals are remodeling so that when the next crisis comes, they’ll be better able to meet it.
item.dc:creator: Debra Kamin
item.media:credit: Hannah Yoon for The New York Times
item.media:description: A new I.C.U. at Doylestown Hospital in Pennsylvania has private rooms meant to shift between intensive care and step-down care.

item.title: Sri Lanka Wins Cricket’s T20 Asia Cup, Bringing Joy to Fans
item.description: The men’s cricket team won the Asia Cup in the T20 format, hours after Sri Lanka won the equivalent championship in women’s netball. Both teams were feted with a parade on Tuesday.
item.dc:creator: Skandha Gunasekara and Mike Ives
item.media:description: Sri Lanka’s men’s cricket team was feted in the capital, Colombo, on Tuesday.

item.title: Lymphatic Drainage: Does it Work? And How to Do It Yourself
item.description: These wellness practices — which center on one invisible network of vessels and nodes — have soared in popularity in recent years. Should you try them?
item.dc:creator: Hannah Seo
item.media:credit: Heather Sten for The New York Times

item.title: How to Cope With Financial Stress
item.description: Experts share tips on how to feel empowered and manage stress as prices continue to rise.
item.dc:creator: Christina Caron

item.title: Is Seltzer Water Just as Healthy as Flat Water?
item.description: Unsweetened carbonated water is a better choice than soda or fruit juice. But don’t overdo it, experts say.
item.dc:creator: Christina Caron
item.media:credit: Aileen Son for The New York Times

item.title: Do Waist Trainers Work?
item.description: Some claim the corset-like garments help wearers slim their midsections. Here’s what the experts say.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.media:credit: Illustration by Tyler Comrie, Photograph by Shutterstock

item.title: How to Handle Menopause Symptoms While Working
item.description: Hot flashes, mood swings and other signs of menopause can cause women to quit their jobs. Here’s how some handle symptoms while working.
item.dc:creator: Melinda Wenner Moyer

item.title: Lillias White Finds Her Goddess for ‘Hadestown’
item.description: The Tony Award-winning actress will step into the role of the musical’s narrator, now known as Missus Hermes.
item.dc:creator: Sarah Bahr
item.media:credit: Sabrina Santiago for The New York Times
item.media:description: The veteran actress Lillias White, 71, will perform the role of Missus Hermes in “Hadestown” eight times per week beginning Sept. 13.
